title: Girl, 11, boy, 13, wounded in separate shootings at same complex
content:
COLUMBIA, SC (WIS) -
Columbia Police officers are investigating after an 11-year-old girl and a 13-year-old boy were struck by bullets at the same apartment complex three days apart.
The 11-year-old girl was hit by one bullet when somebody inside or near a vehicle fired randomly into a crowd of people on Falling Springs Road around 11 p.m. Tuesday.
She was taken to a local hospital to receive medical treatment. She is listed in stable condition.
"This is a child," said resident Ebonie Brazzle. "She was just outside playing and just got hit like that."
Officers are gathering more information about the incident. Authorities blocked the road as they investigated the scene.
Columbia Police Chief Skip Holbrook said on Wednesday a 13-year-old boy was also wounded by gunfire on Sunday night.
"In the same apartment complex on Falling Springs Road a few units down, we had another shooting with the same M.O.," Holbrook said.
He was struck in the neck while inside an apartment when somebody either fired from a vehicle or just outside of a vehicle. He is also in stable condition.
"We feel like that gunfire was random just to make a point," Holbrook said.
Holbrook said they've had very little tips or assistance from the community. "That's troubling," he said.
"We understand that reluctance or fear," Holbrook said. "We're very sensitive to that. Confidentiality is very important to us. We appeal to people's hearts to do what's right for this community."
Brazzle wants the shootings to stop.
"It's just sad," Brazzle said. "You put everyone in danger that stays out here because we live so close to each other. It can go through one wall and just keep on going."
Brazzle hopes people with information will come forward.
"They won't tell because they think they're being a snitch, but they're actually helping," she said. "The more you tell, the safer you are."
If you have any information about these shootings, you are urged to contact Crimestoppers in any of the following ways: Call 1-888-CRIME SC (888-274-6372), Text TIPSC plus your tip info to CRIMES (274637), visit www.midlandscrimestoppers.com and email a tip. Your identity will be kept anonymous, and if your tip leads to an arrest, you could be eligible for a cash reward of up to $1,000.
